## Overview

This section talks about facetting and what are the best practices for facetting.


## tl;dr
<!-- Gimme example -->
I want a nice example. Not tomorrow, not *after breakfast*. NOW! 

<!-- Explanation: -->
Here's a point chart showing tip/bill by gender (Male/Female):

```{r}
library(reshape2)
library(plotly)

sp <- ggplot(tips, aes(x=total_bill, y=tip/total_bill)) + geom_point(shape=1) + ggtitle("Point chart for tip group by gender")

sp + facet_grid(sex ~ .)

```



## the same plot with vertical facetting

```{r}

sp + facet_grid(. ~ sex)

```

# Divide by day, going horizontally and wrapping with 2 columns

```{r}
sp + facet_wrap( ~ day, ncol=2)

```



## Skip to histograms

```{r}
hp <- ggplot(tips, aes(x=total_bill)) + geom_histogram(binwidth=2,colour="white")
hp + facet_grid(sex ~ smoker)


```


## Example of free y scales

```{r}
hp + facet_grid(sex ~ smoker, scales="free_y")


```
This is useful only when you want compare Yes and No across individual genders.
Comparing values of No in Female and No in Male is not a good idea in this plot
